event-1a6291739755f590be25c4eeb4baa9b9.sentence: On 30 June 2009, Pentney signed a six-month contract extension with Leicester City.

event-7a6a62323195deeda55862f7964b782b.sentence: On 1 December 2009, Pentney again signed a six-month contract extension with Leicester City, keeping him at the club until the end final at Wembley Stadium.

event-bbe6ab3a162a04786653bb953e965fd5.sentence: In December 2008, Verma rejoined his former club Leicester City on trial and secured a six-month contract.
event-bbe6ab3a162a04786653bb953e965fd5.context: Verma had previously been released from Leicester City's youth academy.

event-f1457c7659a62a56675630b4296bf850.sentence: In May 2009, Verma was given a one-year contract extension by Leicester City.

event-2cfb803259d5521f1ce4d2068b266769.sentence: On 10 August 2009, Verma joined Crewe Alexandra on loan for three months.
event-2cfb803259d5521f1ce4d2068b266769.context: Verma had joined Crewe Alexandra on trial on 6 August 2009.

event-abda016a503cc8a08c1ac1f3baefb297.sentence: Verma made his debut for Crewe Alexandra on 11 August 2009 in a 2-1 League Cup defeat to Blackpool.
event-abda016a503cc8a08c1ac1f3baefb297.context: Verma replaced James Bailey at half time in his debut match.

event-e0f52f5f90cdb854f1e32d356bd61765.sentence: Verma made his league debut for Crewe Alexandra in a 4-0 win at Grimsby Town on 15 August 2009.

event-9e0ec5455744012a9c7c8823379b74e2.sentence: Verma returned to Leicester City on 3 November 2009, two weeks early having fallen out of favour at Crewe Alexandra.

event-a4a65d8de1b7a21d61ece78752ae6887.sentence: Verma had his first call up to the main Leicester City squad as an unused substitute in a 2-1 win at Blackpool on 6 February 2010.

event-a12e0abb0b55f6a1effb7424951c05ae.sentence: Verma joined Conference National club Histon on loan for the remainder of the 2009-10 season on 26 March 2010.

event-faf0bfda82fdbfcefec9ec65e9a3e202.sentence: In May 2010, Verma was awarded with another contract extension by Leicester City.

event-173f6fb5e30859df0dab057fcab21c12.sentence: Verma made his senior debut for Leicester City as a substitute in a 4-3 League Cup win over Macclesfield on 10 August 2010.

event-9f5ccf90eb4ec06e35320137280331ff.sentence: On 11 August 2010, Verma was part of the Leicester City reserves squad that won the Totesport.com Cup in a 2-1 win over Oldham Athletic reserves at Quorn FC.

event-741d8d486796f3de31d31a6237cf3604.sentence: On 27 August 2010, Verma joined Conference National club Kidderminster Harriers on loan for a month.

event-7d527b9049d07c2e4fdbfeaa3b9e1448.sentence: Verma returned to Leicester City after breaking his hand during his debut for Kidderminster Harriers against Newport County.

event-d189760b6087528ce08339394cab4af3.sentence: On 19 November 2010, Verma joined Darlington on loan until January 2011.

event-afa48e10841ee0f7583c5f14a2cec4c2.sentence: Leicester City confirmed on 14 May 2011 that Verma would not be offered a new contract when it expires on 30 June 2011.

event-624ba3779a99a3c636360597a5677044.sentence: Mills signed for Second Division club Leicester City on 2 March 1989 as part of the deal that saw Phil Turner join County for a fee of £125,000.

event-ee468fcefcc69f6e4cfa898ee43cd1fc.sentence: Mills made his debut for Leicester City two days after joining in a 1-0 victory at home to Walsall on 4 March 1989.

event-c0ea430f148c0f464418cf6808a63d8a.sentence: Mills made 13 consecutive appearances for Leicester City before missing the last two matches of 1988-89.
event-c0ea430f148c0f464418cf6808a63d8a.context: Leicester City finished 15th in the Second Division in the 1988-89 season.

event-77cb7835e58b70b7cc580f2cd8bc8348.sentence: Mills scored his first goal for Leicester City in a 1-0 win away to Stoke City on 25 November 1989.

event-79568bae60442c69bd803e6c823cab3f.sentence: Mills made 30 appearances and scored 4 goals for Leicester City in the 1989-90 season.
event-79568bae60442c69bd803e6c823cab3f.context: Leicester City ranked 13th place in the Second Division in 1989-90.

event-976a9cb24286ef586f7f70aafb50d2e7.sentence: Mills was named Leicester City's Player of the Year for the 1989-90 season.
event-976a9cb24286ef586f7f70aafb50d2e7.context: Mills established himself as a popular player with the supporters.

event-4fc9d34a6f8538d7e29ac785c33e11ee.sentence: Mills made 49 appearances and scored 5 goals for Leicester City in the 1990-91 season.
event-4fc9d34a6f8538d7e29ac785c33e11ee.context: Leicester City avoided relegation to the Third Division by only two points, finishing one place above relegated West Bromwich Albion in 22nd place.

event-be9c6ac120a5b139baf475a982fb2efd.sentence: Mills appeared in all 62 Leicester City fixtures in the 1991-92 season, scoring 7 goals.
event-be9c6ac120a5b139baf475a982fb2efd.context: Leicester City reached the Northern Area final of the Full Members Cup and the Second Division play-offs with a fourth-place finish in the league.

event-c0a5a82592175b24dac678657abf7e18.sentence: Mills was named Leicester City's Player of the Year for the second time in the 1991-92 season.

event-c124461810510763b3f7684bdeec5765.sentence: Leicester City lost 1-0 to Blackburn Rovers at Wembley Stadium in the Second Division play-off final in the 1991-92 season.
event-c124461810510763b3f7684bdeec5765.context: Leicester City had beaten Cambridge United 6-1 on aggregate in the semi-final.

event-eef3aa8034716f1dfceafc619cf073cd.sentence: Mills captained the Leicester City team that reached the First Division play-offs in the 1992-93 season with a sixth place league finish.
event-eef3aa8034716f1dfceafc619cf073cd.context: Leicester City beat Portsmouth 3-2 on aggregate in the semi-final but lost 4-3 to Swindon Town at Wembley Stadium in the final.

event-50d566d88e5ebcac05674073e81cc498.sentence: Mills made 53 appearances for Leicester City in the 1992-93 season.
event-50d566d88e5ebcac05674073e81cc498.context: Mills missed only three of Leicester City's fixtures that season.

event-f0a12bf05539ece6e14dd37e38464ced.sentence: Mills missed the last few months of the 1993-94 season with a foot injury, having made 25 appearances by then.
event-f0a12bf05539ece6e14dd37e38464ced.context: Leicester City finished fourth in the table and made the First Division play-offs for the third successive season.

event-9f7d8e98572135d62d753667eeff1ea4.sentence: Leicester City beat Derby County 2-1 in the First Division play-off final in the 1993-94 season and thus earned promotion to the Premier League.
event-9f7d8e98572135d62d753667eeff1ea4.context: Mills led the team out before the final despite being unable to play due to injury.

event-300e0ae65aebafb22fbc7a535afa6cf6.sentence: Mills returned to Notts County on 26 September 1994 after re-signing for a fee of £50,000.
event-300e0ae65aebafb22fbc7a535afa6cf6.context: Mills had made one Premier League appearance for Leicester City by that point in the 1994-95 season.

event-8a1433cdf2acc358644b5979b048b0ef.sentence: Mills made his debut for Notts County in a 2-0 away defeat to Reading in the First Division on 1 October 1994.

event-d1b54a4649a78e43c2944479c3ae6ee5.sentence: Mills won the Anglo-Italian Cup with Notts County in the 1994-95 season after County beat Ascoli 2-1 in the final.
event-d1b54a4649a78e43c2944479c3ae6ee5.context: Notts County were relegated to the Second Division after finishing 24th in the First Division, with Mills making 43 appearances.

event-4b1f9dac5eb44de2c082821b5940c80e.sentence: Mills picked up his last playing honour as part of the team that won the Anglo-Italian Cup after County beat Ascoli 2–1.
event-4b1f9dac5eb44de2c082821b5940c80e.context: This occurred during the season when Short returned to the team.

event-f334733bde628a3e244a76aa55200b2f.sentence: County were relegated to the Second Division after finishing 24th in the First Division, with Mills making 43 appearances.

event-b04f28c5622870f18412489b74c71bff.sentence: Mills started 1995–96 as County's first-choice right-back before losing his place to Tommy Gallagher.

event-ecb6c042a035b9a5543ca22dd1cbe3c0.sentence: Mills returned to the starting line-up in November 1995.

event-6f74bb7a5fb9cc5a2532cb08a2775e05.sentence: Mills' season was ended by a serious injury in December 1995.

event-f91d006f7fd29c1cf9202c396ae1d999.sentence: County finished fourth in the Second Division in the 1995–96 season.

event-f41a3cdf8f6ddcabfdfd4c538ef22fe3.sentence: County were beaten 2–0 by Bradford in the play-off final in the 1995–96 season.

event-b8209b8bbef3d5f3c7671ecb2080efe9.sentence: County released Mills after he had made 20 appearances in 1995–96.

event-ea718287787b69cdbb293a6b01aa0e63.sentence: Mills retired from professional football in May 1996 as a result of the injury he sustained that season.

event-eac4beac939ab850d2a665d45f667aa0.sentence: Pentney was part of the under-18 squad that won the FA Premier Academy League by beating Sunderland under-18s 4–3 in a penalty shootout in the 2006–07 season.

event-f212b72f990ff007fffffca3009218d8.sentence: İnler joined Premier League club Leicester City on a three-year contract for an undisclosed fee on 19 August 2015.
event-f212b72f990ff007fffffca3009218d8.context: The fee was reported to be £3 million and İnler received the number 33 jersey.

event-4d2fd211e3a1a23ededbded587c7fc03.sentence: İnler made his début for Leicester City three days later, replacing Danny Drinkwater for the final ten minutes of a 1–1 draw with Tottenham Hotspur at King Power Stadium.

event-cfe749b4915992e344c988692430e19d.sentence: İnler was not called up to the Switzerland squad for Euro 2016.

event-c2a605a4c0ceac2e555dba07ed3677ed.sentence: İnler played the minimum five league games required to be eligible for a winners medal when Leicester became 2015–16 Premier League champions.

event-79e99900e7414df629e5bd2b7643c8a1.sentence: Vincent joined Colchester United on loan until the end of the 2008–09 season in March 2009.

event-fb72d8b5200bf4eddce9864622ed14a9.context: The first game was a 7–1 win over Norwich City, and Paul Lambert was replaced by new boss Aidy Boothroyd.

event-9c84fd556930b47ebde2d12dbb8ad371.sentence: Vincent featured 42 times and scored five goals for Colchester United in the 2010–11 season.

event-e08e9398276cd32045c4b873f175624e.sentence: Vincent missed six weeks at the start of the 2011–12 season with a knee ligament injury.
event-e08e9398276cd32045c4b873f175624e.context: Vincent admitted he feared the injury could have ended his career and hinted at a move to a Midlands club.

event-9acee0080ca8e68dc764e32955f59ca3.sentence: Vincent was struck down by a hamstring injury in December 2011, which kept him out of action for several weeks.
event-9acee0080ca8e68dc764e32955f59ca3.context: His injuries limited him to just 12 appearances in the 2011–12 campaign.

event-4472f3f26debc83e4c9eb978d16c7602.sentence: John Ward confirmed at the end of the 2011–12 season that Vincent had played his last game for Colchester United.
event-4472f3f26debc83e4c9eb978d16c7602.context: Vincent's injuries had limited him to just 12 appearances in the campaign.

event-44c5a41d851301e769df0c5739b19a46.sentence: Vasquez joined newly created MLS team C.D. Chivas USA as assistant coach on January 2, 2005.
event-44c5a41d851301e769df0c5739b19a46.context: Vasquez joined after one season as assistant with the Los Angeles Galaxy.

event-f012b6aca24b36b2e322042a56ee4b0d.sentence: Vasquez worked as the assistant to Jürgen Klinsmann at German club FC Bayern Munich between July 2008 and April 2009.
event-f012b6aca24b36b2e322042a56ee4b0d.context: Vasquez left when Klinsmann was dismissed due to bad results.

event-0e7e294cb94f691688f3d8dbaf83fa8c.sentence: Vasquez was hired to his first head coaching job on December 2, 2009, at former club Chivas.

event-e2082ce18b0510a6d6db8cb1c8447a2d.sentence: Vasquez was recalled by Klinsmann as an assistant coach for a friendly against Mexico on August 11, 2011.
event-e2082ce18b0510a6d6db8cb1c8447a2d.context: Klinsmann had been named head coach of the United States men's national team.

event-e51bf3e0de5c14022761624aa6cdf5fa.sentence: Vasquez was replaced by Tab Ramos on March 31, 2014.
event-e51bf3e0de5c14022761624aa6cdf5fa.context: The replacement occurred less than 3 months before the World Cup, relegating Vasquez to scouting and match observations.

event-00871f8167bd8451c8c317bcbd000895.sentence: Guppy was recruited for the position of assistant coach to Gary Smith at Colorado Rapids after a season as player-coach at Rochester.
event-00871f8167bd8451c8c317bcbd000895.context: Rochester released Guppy from his duties, allowing him to move onto a higher level of coaching.

event-f26572e35ec0c077b2009771e1d70400.sentence: Guppy was assistant coach at the Colorado Rapids for three years, from 2009 to 2012.
event-f26572e35ec0c077b2009771e1d70400.context: During his time at the club the Rapids lifted the MLS Cup in 2010.

event-1d2626c2b596c1b3a6c76a884f7a59e3.sentence: He was assistant coach at the Colorado Rapids for three years, from 2009 to 2012.

event-57c51af52d8bdf02fcbc804af8821aea.sentence: In March 2012, Guppy reunited with his old boss Martin O'Neill at Sunderland to work as a part-time coach, giving extra specialised sessions on technical work to Black Cats young players.

event-7ce98947ecc8c8df385eee4e65ef56c2.sentence: A few months later he settled into the role on a full-time basis.

event-0e795267c934c06b16530f16501d46b8.sentence: In April 2013, Guppy followed O'Neill out of Sunderland as incoming manager Paolo Di Canio appointed his own coaching staff.

event-e4ffadcb47e74f2d1964b9c4c58dd6b6.sentence: In 2014, he joined O'Neill's coaching staff to specifically coach the wingers and strikers of the Republic of Ireland national side.

event-b264b0cbb21ea6ce4665bd4ae9d7a615.sentence: He helped former teammate Neil Aspin to coach Port Vale during 2018-19 pre-season.

event-133238184ea37a7b5d09d29e24d8cfd3.sentence: O'Neill was sacked by Ireland in November 2018 following relegation out of the UEFA Nations League B Group 3, and Guppy also lost his position.

event-c416f526d267b7afb9c22b88b4fd213e.sentence: In June 2020, Wilson joined non-league club Ilkeston Town in a player-coach role, following a three-year break from football.

event-8cb585d475a6dd435f1cb1ebdbb2e79c.sentence: In November 2019, Pentney announced his retirement from playing football in order to take up a full-time position as head of academy goalkeeping at Ipswich Town.

event-d4bc4bc91f9f382ab19c4495d23316e6.sentence: He was the coach of Inglewood United in 2007.

event-3180a1396b0bf0bb82f981b50325cc06.sentence: He was the coach of Perth boys school Hale Schools 1st XI Soccer side in 2008.

event-b978b9af6b400305ac00a6e0714c6ce0.sentence: He was variously the coach of the Perth Glory NPL U20s team and the Perth Glory's Womens team between 2015 and 2020.

event-f3d632fb9629aefe4733fd95dcf639a1.sentence: In October 1963 he returned to Tottenham Hotspur to become the assistant manager under Bill Nicholson.
event-f3d632fb9629aefe4733fd95dcf639a1.context: He remained with Bill Nicholson until Nicholson departed in August 1974.

event-2cd563a36bbbf7bc249c82ebde9160c4.sentence: He remained with Bill Nicholson until Nicholson departed in August 1974.
event-2cd563a36bbbf7bc249c82ebde9160c4.context: He had returned to Tottenham Hotspur as assistant manager in October 1963.

event-dc4a7887a53c940963fbe339fc13edc8.sentence: Baily also quit White Hart Lane the following month.
event-dc4a7887a53c940963fbe339fc13edc8.context: This followed Bill Nicholson's departure from Tottenham Hotspur in August 1974.

event-d186d90d894b116550d24aeafa7c9b39.sentence: Following sixteen years of service, he had a testimonial match in 1993 between Spurs and Enfield on the day that Alan Sugar sacked Terry Venables as manager of Spurs.
event-d186d90d894b116550d24aeafa7c9b39.context: A large crowd turned up in order to protest against the sacking.

event-2aaa759f923350f3d690702129ca65bc.sentence: Eddie Baily died on 13 October 2010 at Welwyn Garden City after a short illness.

event-915dad14928f810f82fc0a37ffa226e8.sentence: He was survived by wife, Elsie (married December 1952).

event-948a1b3e40044f2f35ae6d1923b459db.sentence: Vilanova started his coaching career in 2003-04, being in charge of Tercera División side FC Palafrugell and suffering relegation to Primera Catalana.

event-7b1d9a478913d2da13c8d2d902eb4dd2.sentence: In the summer of 2008, after leading the reserves to promotion to Segunda División B, Vilanova and Guardiola were assigned to the Barcelona first team, replacing Dutch duo Frank Rijkaard and Johan Neeskens.

event-e5ebb1501158c1bd7404725a5e500d56.sentence: On 27 April 2012, at the press conference in which Barcelona confirmed Guardiola's departure, it was also announced that Vilanova would be his successor.

event-f622f9422f5b089029b32f24baa617a8.sentence: On 15 June he signed a two-year contract.
event-f622f9422f5b089029b32f24baa617a8.context: This followed the announcement that Vilanova would succeed Guardiola as Barcelona manager.

event-9921894a5786418839f37591586c8638.sentence: In November 2012, in a La Liga match Vilanova named an entire starting 11 of Barcelona academy graduates.

event-231f3a8f533003327d1fea7ca5ff4123.sentence: On 19 December 2012, Barcelona announced that Vilanova was suffering from parotid gland cancer for the second time.
event-231f3a8f533003327d1fea7ca5ff4123.context: He was first diagnosed on 22 November of the previous year.

event-fe7701e60c14b1f1cb31171db634f30d.context: This followed Barcelona's announcement that he was suffering from parotid gland cancer.

event-4f795ee206377655c68842af66e814c3.sentence: Vilanova returned to the bench in late March 2013.
event-4f795ee206377655c68842af66e814c3.context: Assistant Jordi Roura had taken over as head coach during Vilanova's absence.

event-718a4a5759002e9f35148c2f696f78fe.sentence: On 19 July 2013, Vilanova resigned as Barcelona manager as he relapsed from his condition.
event-718a4a5759002e9f35148c2f696f78fe.context: He stated that the related treatment was not compatible with the status of a professional manager.

event-da6f936297340a852d344598154cc409.sentence: Vilanova died on 25 April 2014, due to complications from cancer, at the age of 45 after suffering a relapse the previous week.

event-4ac59f25ac62f0236c46fb83f6cc32e3.sentence: After retiring at the end of the 2017 season, Hines remained with Orlando City and joined the Orlando City Youth Soccer coaching staff in March 2018.

event-62f10b36775f250e360f672dfde4e5ed.sentence: In May 2020, Hines was named as an assistant coach of Orlando City's NWSL affiliate, Orlando Pride.
event-62f10b36775f250e360f672dfde4e5ed.context: Prior to the appointment, he had already been working with the Pride in training sessions and in player scouting.

event-b5559ac3986fcc3a373e2a7c5dfafd31.sentence: On 13 June 2016, Flahavan retired from playing when Flahavan was appointed the goalkeeper coach of Leeds United as part of the backroom staff to new head coach Garry Monk.
event-b5559ac3986fcc3a373e2a7c5dfafd31.context: Flahavan had a loan spell at Leeds during his playing days and was a former teammate of Monk during his Southampton days.

event-2a05b132eb59895553c461554a48851c.sentence: On 21 June 2017, Flahavan followed Monk to Middlesbrough after Monk resigned as Leeds manager.

event-91135f50a8fd2b4cc40126e0576bbbce.sentence: Flahavan was appointed goalkeeping coach of EFL Championship club Birmingham City when Monk took over as manager on 4 March 2018.

event-0ff86f16f57de7d5f2932a59ed082027.sentence: On 12 August 2020, Flahavan joined Sheffield Wednesday as their goalkeeper coach.

event-b5086722c2f979a267bc22046e4b8208.sentence: Flahavan left Sheffield Wednesday on 9 November 2020, when Garry Monk left the club.

event-89f3d32882b125abd11ee308dd157764.sentence: Pat Duncan was born on April 8, 1960.

event-1501460650450f30b95042837694b17f.sentence: Pat Duncan served as leader of the Yukon Liberal Party from 1998 to 2005.

event-586eba84e70f05ffa03d7c13a60855b1.sentence: Pat Duncan served as the sixth Premier of Yukon from 2000 until 2002.
event-586eba84e70f05ffa03d7c13a60855b1.context: Pat Duncan was the first Liberal premier of the Yukon and the first female premier in the Yukon.

event-a86a5a39786b5b6ff8e2f95f39587acd.sentence: Pat Duncan became the first Liberal premier of the Yukon in 2000.

event-a247b9955a9f46ae0776e09a86332e79.sentence: Pat Duncan became the first female premier in the Yukon in 2000.

event-3cfa211935afcd824a7373f1ff5d158e.sentence: Pat Duncan became the second woman in Canadian history to win the premiership of a province or territory through a general election in 2000.

event-9fb762754ad94d6f34f68acc4e47fa8c.sentence: Pat Duncan became the first woman in Canadian history to win a premiership by defeating an incumbent premier in 2000.

event-a885d44a7e618068f13cc3d5808827cb.sentence: Pat Duncan became the first woman in Canadian history to win a premiership by defeating a male opponent in 2000.

event-dfeec3bfa52926677f32d01e712d2b04.sentence: The Yukon general election was held in 2002.

event-4db0159c4cd778cfe53aa6b1ed1b563c.sentence: The Yukon general election was held in 2000.

event-7a21b9d17f3cf08e96b48468f0a07de6.sentence: The Yukon general election was held in 1996.

event-2b0ea51e994cecba17fad3bb6b645257.context: This followed a brief spell with Braintree Town where he made two appearances.

event-bbfee323e30d32cc07606ff08636c1bd.sentence: Maidenhead United achieved promotion to the National League in 2017.
event-bbfee323e30d32cc07606ff08636c1bd.context: Pentney was ever-present over the three seasons including this promotion.

event-e10357cde9f1c8e856c23befae39784a.sentence: Pentney was sent off at Havant & Waterlooville in October 2018.
event-e10357cde9f1c8e856c23befae39784a.context: This ended his streak of 148 consecutive league games playing the full 90 minutes.

event-32e5090f31ab494a0194e8d2e2ff13a3.sentence: Pentney left Maidenhead United at the end of the 2018–19 season.

event-414bc491f81be13ac8022080e023ba8e.sentence: Carl Benjamin Pentney was born on 29 October 1989.

event-1945315ed131d5333a7d36bfcd70334a.sentence: Carl Benjamin Pentney played as a goalkeeper as an English former professional footballer.

event-5466e81d53172f7eeaf151de37ddf3d8.sentence: Carl Benjamin Pentney is currently the head of academy goalkeeping at Ipswich Town.

event-22517c245bdbb11b3c9340b7e176029c.sentence: Duncan was first elected to the Yukon Legislative Assembly in the 1996 general election.
event-22517c245bdbb11b3c9340b7e176029c.context: Duncan was elected as a Liberal to represent the Porter Creek South riding, a riding located in Whitehorse.

event-3898b67398a364de8ba40694afb81fdc.sentence: In the 1996 general election, Piers McDonald (New Democratic Party) won a majority government.
event-3898b67398a364de8ba40694afb81fdc.context: Duncan was one of three Liberals elected in this election.

event-01886699d38c1f30ca6de6e2c335c69b.sentence: In 1998, Duncan was elected leader of the Yukon Liberal Party.

event-fccac3a04c2415de62a7f72fd7e34631.sentence: From 1998-2000, Duncan served as the Leader of the Official Opposition in the legislature.

event-deb3ae478875f9317cabdb5f095fe4bc.sentence: In the 2000 general election, Duncan led the Yukon Liberal Party to a majority government, defeating New Democratic incumbent Piers McDonald.
event-deb3ae478875f9317cabdb5f095fe4bc.context: The Liberals were elected in 10 ridings and received 42.7% of the popular vote.

event-0ea789f217065fec2de92c180b0ed225.sentence: Early in 2002, the Liberal majority was reduced to a minority after the defection of three Liberal MLAs: Mike McLarnon, Don Roberts and Wayne Jim.
event-0ea789f217065fec2de92c180b0ed225.context: The catalyst for the defections was reported to be Duncan's allegedly heavy-handed and secretive leadership style.

event-fdd5cd3297712b699f3c0522d32314ac.sentence: On October 4, 2002, Duncan called a general election for November 4, 2002.
event-fdd5cd3297712b699f3c0522d32314ac.context: This was only two years into Duncan's five-year term, and the rationale was to achieve certainty in the legislature.

event-58b93d5caa7369d826361541b20a848c.sentence: The Yukon Liberals were reduced to only one seat after the November 4, 2002 election - Duncan's own riding of Porter Creek South.
event-58b93d5caa7369d826361541b20a848c.context: Yukon Party leader Dennis Fentie, a former NDP MLA, led his new party to victory.

event-9a5117bc8b856b525f9b5299648d2852.sentence: At the 2005 Yukon Liberal Party leadership convention, Duncan was defeated by Arthur Mitchell by a margin of 357 votes to 303.

event-13c5a299e0f890488b49d3c186012b79.sentence: Duncan did not seek re-election in the 2006 general election.
event-13c5a299e0f890488b49d3c186012b79.context: Duncan cited health concerns for not seeking re-election.
